UNESCO Did NOT Recognise ‘Jana Gana Mana’ as ‘World’s Best Anthem’
==================================================================
The message, which has been in circulation since 2008, has been debunked by UNESCO.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Updated: 03 Jul 2018, 11:37 AM IST
2 min read
!
i
Aa
Aa
Small
Aa
Medium
Aa
Large
A recurring email/message that has graced our inboxes is definitely one declaring that the UNESCO had recognised our national anthem 'Jana Gana Mana', as the world's best anthem.
The message, like many other rumours connected to UNESCO, is fake.
!
!
Don’t fall for fake news,  to check out The Quint’s WebQoof stories.
ADVERTISEMENT
This particular message has been in circulation since 2008, reported . According to the report, the message was circulated as a ploy to ‘increase membership’ in a Yahoo Groups site called MumbaiHangOut.
The channel had then reached out to UNESCO to verify the news, when Sue Williams, Chief, Editorial, Press Relations and Unesco Courier, Bureau of Public Information, UNESCO, wrote back debunking the 'announcement'.
> We are aware of several blogs in India reporting this story, but can assure you that UNESCO has made no such announcement concerning the anthem of India or any country.
Several other messages on similar lines include the UNESCO having credited PM Narendra Modi as "the best prime minister in the world", and the new Rs 2,000 note as "the best currency in the world." These messages too have been , as the UNESCO does not give out such awards.
(_Not convinced of a story you came across on social media and want it verified? Send us the details at_ _WebQoof@TheQuint.com and we'll fact-check it for you. You can also read all our fact-checked stories_ _.)_
_(__At The Quint, we are answerable only to our audience. Play an active role in shaping our journalism by . Because the truth is worth it...[Content truncated]

It covers issues related to politics, society, and culture, emphasizing accuracy and transparency. Its commitment to factual reporting enhances its credibility, though it should still be approached with scrutiny typical of any media source.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: Similar to evidence0, this evidence indicates that the claim about UNESCO recognizing 'Jana Gana Mana' as the world's best anthem is untrue. It provides historical context around the misinformation and cites direct responses from UNESCO, making it highly relevant for assessing the validity of the claim.

Follow Us On:
'India anthem' email false: Unesco
'India anthem' email false: Unesco
==================================
An email announcing that the Unesco has declared the Indian National Anthem as the best in the world may have landed in your inbox, writes Elora Sen.  
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Listen to Story
Advertisement
!
]
Kolkata,UPDATED: Sep 30, 2008 14:17 IST
"Congratsssssssssssssss………..Proud to be an Indian." An email titled this may have landed in your inbox in the recent past, announcing that the Unesco has declared the Indian National Anthem as the best in the world.  
Sure it's an achievement you would have thought. But why after so many years, you might have asked? And why have there been no official announcement or any celebrations? After all it was an UNESCO award, and not a joke.  
But that is exactly what it is. A rather imprudent joke, playing with the sentiment of millions of Indians.  
When India Today wrote to the UNESCO asking for details and clarifications regarding this 'announcement', Sue Williams (Chief, Editorial, Press Relations and Unesco Courier, Bureau of Public Information, Unesco) wrote back that no such award has been announced.  
She wrote that the UNESCO was aware of this mail, but it was not true.  
"We are aware of several blogs in India reporting this story, but can assure you that Unesco has made no such announcement concerning the anthem of India or any country," she wrote.  
So why is this elaborate hoax? The mail, that comes with a picture of Rabindranath Tagore, the tricolour, the Ashoka Pillar and the text of_Jana Gana Mana_, India's National Anthem, looks innocent enough. It also carries a text message detailing the announcement and the history of the anthem.  
...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: India Today is a well-established news outlet with a good reputation for in-depth analysis and credible information. Its investigative journalism and coverage of various issues make it a reliable source for news. However, like many media outlets, it may exhibit some editorial bias.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence reports on an email claim that UNESCO labeled the Indian anthem as the best and notes UNESCO's denial of such announcements. It significantly aids in challenging the credibility of the claim, making it pertinent for understanding the truth about the declaration.

content.content:
[Content truncated]...- later became a Pakistani Nationalist , he is highly revered figure in Pakistan and is considered as one of the masterminds of partition\ \] \ \] and that is why choosing a song written by a man who played a great role in the partition of the country as a national anthem was never a wise decision.
* * *
Compared to the other two-Jana Gana Mana was less controversial—it was written by Rabindranath Tagore, one of the most respected figure in modern India and the first Indian to receive a Nobel prize.
!
While there are some people who still believe that he wrote that anthem for King George \ \] but it was never a big issue back then and that’s why our founding fathers found Jana Gana Mana to be a better option than the former two.  
Other than it Jana Gana Mana was was language neutral - using just a string of names of India's major regions and had no religious connotations.
~Rajdeep.

The Indian national anthem, "Jana Gana Mana," was composed by Rabindranath Tagore. The version that is officially recognized as the national anthem of India is the one composed by Tagore himself. There are various renditions and performances of the anthem by different artists and musicians, but the original composition by Tagore is considered the best version and is the one that holds the official status as the national anthem of India.
It's important to note that the national anthem is a symbol of national unity and pride for the country, and it is typically performed in a dignified manner tha
Continue Reading
The Indian national anthem, "Jana Gana Mana," was composed by Rabindranath Tagore. The version that is officially recognized as the national anthem of India is the one composed by Tagore himself. There are various renditions and performances of the anthem by different artists and musicians, but the original composition by Tagore is considered the best version and is the one that holds the official status as the national anthem of India.
It's important to note that the national anthem is a symbol of national unity and pride for the country, and it is typically performed in a dignified manner that respects its significance. While there may be variations in how the anthem is performed, the original composition by Rabindranath Tagore remains the definitive version.

QA.Question: Does the video provide credible evidence that UNESCO recognized 'Jana Gana Mana' as the best national anthem?
QA.Answer:
The video does not provide credible evidence that UNESCO recognized 'Jana Gana Mana' as the best national anthem. In fact, there is substantial evidence to contradict this claim. 

1. UNESCO itself has clarified that the claims circulating since 2008 regarding 'Jana Gana Mana' being declared the best national anthem are merely rumors. This misinformation has been debunked multiple times by credible sources and UNESCO has stated that no such announcement has been made regarding India's national anthem or any country's anthem.

2. The prevalence of this misinformation is evident, as it has been circulated widely on social media and email, often with misleading or fabricated captions suggesting that such a declaration was made by UNESCO.

3. Other reputable news sources have also reported that UNESCO has not recognized 'Jana Gana Mana' in any such capacity, reinforcing that this claim is a fabrication.

Taken together, these points strongly indicate that the video does not provide any credible evidence supporting the claim that 'Jana Gana Mana' is recognized by UNESCO as the best national anthem.
